Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2012 11:39PM fluffqueen01 wrote: I only had to quit taking mine for three days before and two after. However, I read on hear about all the docs who said ten days. I stopped at 6 before and started at three after. Out of that I had 4 glorious days with very mild warm flashes. Now it is back to normal

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2011 07:45PM fluffqueen01 wrote: REdsky, I haven't red this entire thread yet, but regarding the bain pump...I had one and the nurses in the hospital told me the same thing...I could take it out myself, noooo problem. I told them there was no way that was happening. I have many medical friends who offered as I am not one at all. As it turned out my BS was going out of town so I had to see her on the day it finished up. the nurse removed it. Those things are in there like a foot! It did not hurt. I felt the tugging, but no pain. Same with my drains (and I wasted two good pain pills on those thinking it would hurt). I was totally freaked out over how long the pain tubing was. I would never take it out myself, and if I had, can assure you I would have stopped long before getting all of that tubing out, sure that there must be something wrong!

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 12:34AM fluffqueen01 wrote: Just went back and checked the ingredients of the stuff I bought at the dollar store. No methylparabens, at least nothing that says that or the synonyms that mean methylparaben. There are so many I don't know how we ever know exactly what is and isn't one. Anyhow, I am not sure this stuff is really meant for my hair and may be meant more for African or Indian texture, but I am going to keep using it until my hair is longer. Based on the ingredients, I think it would make a good general moisturizer. I slathered some on the foobs after my shower too. It is called Softee Indian Hemp hair and scalp treatment. Says its light and natural..not so much. Main ingredient is petrolatum (it has vaselineish kind of texture) but then has jojoba oil, sunflower oil,wheat germ oil, vitamin e, indian hemp oil, jaborandi oil, nettle oil, rosemary oil, birch oil, burdock oil, rosehips oil, irishmoss oil, coltsfoot oil, dandelion oil, yellow dock oil, elder flowers oil,brewers yeast oil,shavegrass oil,echinacea oil,wild cherry bark oil,nepeta Cataria. The only bad thing I can find is the second to last ingredient BHT, the preservative. I know it isn't good and can cause cancer in rats, but they are feeding them massive amounts. And they also use it in so much normal stuff I figure I unknowingly ingest itin the food preservatives. It is supposed to ensure maximum hair growth. LOL.  I am just going to slather away until my hair is just growing while I watch it!

Think of this as that plus a bonus of natural oils. They may grow back in within two days!

Posts.Content: May 25, 2012 11:45PM fluffqueen01 wrote: Laurie, I kept my fingers iced through chemo, no issues, and then continued through herceptin, just in case, although no one seems to know if it helps. Missed one time with the ice. Toward the end of Herceptin (which was March 20), they started to lift. I had also been getting shellac manicures. I stopped in February because my nails were breaking and lifting really low, and they were so thin it hurt to remove the shellac stuff. I have been babying them using Nailtiques, etc. Everytime I think they are getting better, the area that broke and lifted before do again. My thumbs are the worst, and my other nails don't seem to be growing, are very bendy, and the least little bump seems like it causes an area to raise.It is frustrating. I am thinking of going to someone, but not sure who, and am also not sure I want to know what they would tell me. I don't want to have my nails removed.
Posts.Title: Long term side effects lalere fluffqueen01

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2011 10:15PM fluffqueen01 wrote: My last chemo was June 13. I had enough hair throughout the 12 weekly doses to get by and toward the end wore a baseball cap and never lost eyelashes or eyebrows. Two weeks after chemo up to four weeks, I started shedding hair again and lost my eyebrows and lashes. They were already growing in however and grew in literally in a week (at least the eyebrows). Eyelashes were also quick and seem thicker. Hair is another story. It is 13 weeks, and I have a covering, but that is about it. Top is about an inch but really not filled in well in spots, or so light it doesn't look filled in. Back and sides seem thicker, but are laying very flat to my head. I tried to spike it all with no luck. Then, I had the brilliant idea I would try a semi-permanent color rinse that washes out in 6-10 washes. Bought a blonde color and promptly turned the top of my head yellow. My husband gets a good laugh out of it. And it is taking much longer than 6-10 washes to go away! I'll be waiting until the end of October for my hair dresser now! I am also on Herceptin and thought that might slow things down, but I had hoped I would have a couple inches and be able to go without the wig. Hate the thought I might be wearing for another year! I'm not done with Herceptin until next March. I take biotin, multi, and b12 to help with hair growth. I've also tried Nioxin shampoo and scalp treatment. Not sure I think it does much. Ran across some kind of Hemp creme at the dollar store today that you put on your head and it is supposed to help your hair grow. Forgot to check for methylparabens...I am sure they will probably be there. Smells great!

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2011 10:45PM fluffqueen01 wrote: Hi all, there is a thread somewhere that I think is head covering options for hair loss. There are a couple of sites that have really neat head scarf things and will send you one for free. Also, if you have the Look Good Feel Better program in your area, do it for sure. It's abiout two hours, with make up tips when you are going through chemo, etc.  You get a bag full of makeup. At mine, they passed around some hats that people had made that are great for just wearing around the house. Cotton and so soft. Then at the end, she gave a wig to everyone and had an assortment so she came pretty close with everyone's hair color. There were just three of us in the class I took and it was a lot of fun. I still had hair then so didn't try on the wig. It was shorter than my style so I didn't think I would ever wear it and just put it away. Got it out the other day and decided it was pretty cute. Went to a wig styling place where they trimmed the bangs, spiked it up and little and now it is really fun. The program is completely free.

I have an appointment with a sedond oncologist ont he 23rd and plan to ask more about that.

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2011 06:26PM fluffqueen01 wrote: My pathology was all from my biopsy as they took it all out, with clean margins that were still clean at bmx a month later. I went through the path report with my bs and my onc. At the end of the day, I think they are still working on the accuracy of recurrence using those factors. Like blue pearl noted, my onc said they were factors as part of the whole picture but not reliable as a single factor. I read the same thing concerning mitotic rate being a good predictor, but also not sure it is fully proven

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2011 03:16AM fluffqueen01 wrote: Glad to hear the great survival rates!  Especially with the Triple Positive girls like me. I am currently going through treatment with Taxol and Herceptin. Fortunately, few side effects, other than hair starting to thin. I don't know that I will ever use the word survivor but I do like no evidence of disease or NED. My onc throws around the stat of 95% cure rate for my stage and type. I sure hope so! Healthy and long life wishes to all of you! Jill
Posts.Title: How many years have you been a Survivor? IllinoisNancy Lou789

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 03:33PM fluffqueen01 wrote: I had my bmx on 2/28. It was not bad at all. PS put in a pain pump for four days which was wonderful and I basically had no pain, only soreness. I did not take any pain pills after 24 hours.Two drains came out 7 days later and the other two are scheduled for next Tuesday, although one of them has all of a sudden started draining a lot at night, so I may have to keep that one a while. He has allowed me to start the basic pt exercises which are helping to relieve a lot of the tightness. Expanders feel tight but not painful so far. He started me with 250 cc's, so I don't have a ton more to go. I am stopping at 500 I think. It feels weirdest between my breasts in the ribcage area. Very tight. Because I am her2 positive I am scheduled to begin chemo with Herceptin on 3/22 but may have to postpone that due to the one drain issue. I am starting to get out and about which feels great!

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2011 05:26PM fluffqueen01 wrote: Judy-mine started me with benadryl, cut that in half the second time and then nothing. I had some of the joint pain that special k noted when I went to the every three week dose dense herceptin. Also tired and some mld queasiness. Onc said I could go every week, but As special k noted, omaz mentioned increasing infusion time, so I thought I would start with that. It has helped immensely.

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2011 08:14PM fluffqueen01 wrote: I had 12 weeks of taxol, weekly. Didn't lose all my hair nor my eyelashes and eyebrows. Hair thinned significantly, but I could wear a baseball cap and get by for workouts. Eyelashes fell out mostly on the bottom right at the end, but they are growing back in. Brows just thinned. I am going to start latisse in the next week.  My plan, had they fallen out during chemo was to start it then and my onc was ok with it. I probably wouldn't start it in advance. I don't think it stops them from falling out.
